posts.title: Nectar (2014)
posts.excerpt: Synopsis: A round chamber in a park, where five women perform a ritual they know well. The queen gives her nectar. Yet a new cycle is already under way.

posts.title: Devil Bat’s Daughter
posts.excerpt: Synopsis: Wishing to dispose of his wife, psychiatrist Doctor Elliott makes his patient Nina think that she suffers from a compulsion to kill. He drugs Nina, murders his wife and leaves evidence that points to Nina. The latter, pre-conditioned by Elliott, also thinks she is guilty.

posts._title: Morgan Dews – Must Read After My Death (2007)
posts.title: Must Read After My Death
posts.excerpt: Synopsis: A grandmother dies and leaves behind hours of secret film and audio recordings as well as an envelope with the words “Must read after my death”, which reveal a dark history for her family to discover.

posts._title: Maroun Bagdadi – Beyrouth ya Beyrouth AKA Beirut, Oh Beirut (1975)
posts.title: Beyrouth ya Beyrouth
posts.excerpt: In the aftermath of the 1967 defeat, four young Lebanese try to figure out their places in a society whose rules seem to have changed. It proved to be an extraordinary anticipation of the civil war that would engulf the country while the film was being edited.

posts._title: Jean Rollin – Les démoniaques aka Demoniacs aka Curse of the Living Dead (1974)
posts.title: Les démoniaques
posts.excerpt: Quote: Jean Rollin’s surreal pirate film takes place on land amidst the skeletons of beached and plundered ships, the legacy of a cutthroat band of “wreckers” who lure ships into the shallows. When a pair of survivors, young girls glowing in white nightgowns, wander through the shallows seeking help from the merry quartet, they are …
posts.titleEnglish: Demoniacs aka Curse of the Living Dead

posts._title: Aditya Vikram Sengupta – Asha Jaoar Majhe AKA Labour of Love (2014)
posts.title: Asha Jaoar Majhe
posts.excerpt: Quote: There’s very little in common between Asha Jaoar Majhe and In The Mood For Love, but somehow Aditya Vikram Sengupta’s debut feature reminded me a lot of Wong Kar Wai’s classic romance. Perhaps it’s to do with the abiding images of the two protagonists walking/cycling along narrow city alleys with little spoken yet a …

posts._title: Joseph W. Sarno – Abigail Lesley Is Back in Town (1975)
posts.title: Abigail Lesley Is Back in Town
posts.excerpt: A seductive woman, who left her small fishing town long ago after being caught with another woman’s husband, returns to shake up the place by seducing everyone, including the woman and her girlfriends. Starring: Rebecca Brooke, Jennifer Welles, Jennifer Jordan, Eric Edwards, Jamie Gillis, Chris Jordan, Julia Sorel & Susan Sloan.

posts.title: 17 minute intarziere
posts.excerpt: Romanian student film, shot on 35mm. Now the guy is 33 years old and already can be proud of his PALME D’OR Romanian filmmaker Catalin Mitulescu spent numerous years working in Austria, Hungary, Poland and Italy. In 2001, he graduated from the Film Directing Department at the University of Film and Theatre in Bucharest. His …

posts.title: Szamanka
posts.excerpt: ANDRZEJ ZULAWSKI’S adaptation of Manuela Gretkowska’s provocative and hugely successful novel reaches new extremes in the depiction of brutality, sex, and passion as it tells the story of a young(ish) anthropologist driven by the mystery surrounding the death of a recently discovered shaman; and his growing obsession with an enigmatic yet violently perverse beauty known …

posts.title: Tongue
posts.excerpt: Pornographic Blacksploitation. Quasi, a Black man with a 9 inch tongue lives alone with a pet frog. Since his girl friend left him 2 years ago he has become mute and used by everyone. While playing chess by himself on a park bench he is humiliated by a young woman. He’s then sexually taken advantage …
